body:
On my machine, this happens if I leave off --framework and use --inprocess!

We obviously need to fix this for the release. We also need to examine all the various paths through the creation of the AppDomain, depending on settings, simplify the logic and ensure that all paths work the same  way.

issue.title: assembly.config not found when running from .nunit project

milestone.title: Closed Without Action
milestone.description: This milestone contains closed issues where no action was taken. This includes questions, issues that could not be reproduced, rejected ideas, invalid issues, etc.

issue.body:
I have several different test assemblies in various folders that I have configured using an nunit project file. 
Here is the contents of the config. 

``` <NUnitProject>
<Settings activeconfig="active" appbase="c:\projects\hyena\source\Tests\"/>
    <Config name="active" binpath="Buzzard.Tests.Unit\bin\Debug\;FileService.Test.Unit\bin\Debug\;Hyena.Tests.Framework.Unit\bin\Debug\">
        <assembly path="Buzzard.Tests.Unit\bin\Debug\Buzzard.Tests.Unit.dll"/>
        <assembly path="FileService.Tests.Unit\bin\Debug\FileService.Tests.Unit.dll"/>
        <assembly path="Hyena.Tests.Framework.Unit\bin\Debug\Hyena.Tests.Framework.Unit.dll"/>
    </Config>
</NUnitProject>
```

 Each test assembly has its own config file named to match the test assembly (i.e. Buzzard.Tests.Unit.dll.config) that resides next to the corresponding test assembly. 

The nunit project file resides in the appbase directory.  

When I run this from the command line with the following 
    `'C:\Program Files (x86)\NUnit.org\bin\nunit-console.exe' testconfig.nunit`
the test assemblies are not able to find their own config files.  I logged the `AppDomain.CurrentDomain.SetupInformation.ConfigurationFile` to see what was being picked up and the output was basically the correct file name in the wrong location:

```
FileService.Tests.Unit.FileServiceUnitTests.DeleteFile_SavedFile_DeleteIsNotCalled
c:\projects\hyena\source\Tests\FileService.Tests.Unit.dll.config
```

So in this case I would expect the source for the config to be  `c:\projects\hyena\source\Tests\FileService.Tests.Unit\bin\Debug\FileService.Tests.Unit.dll.config` but it is looking in the appbase folder for that file instead of the location where the test assembly is. 

The same set of suites run without failure through VS with the VS test adapter.  They also work if I just pass the file list for the test assemblies directly to the command line without using the nunit project config. 

I discovered this issue when trying to run the suites through TeamCity on our build server.  TeamCity generates a nunit project on the fly in order to execute the tests through the console.  

I feel like I may be missing something fundamental in my setup because it seems like a pretty common configuration and was surprised that no one else seems to have encountered this issue. 

Thanks,

Allen

issue.title: Issue 1015
issue.body:
This fixes #1015. It's a bigger change than I really like to do between two RCs but it's an important issue.

I reworked the order of setting up the domain to make it easier to test and added some tests.

I also implemented a basic policy change as compared to NUnit V2: when running a project file named project.nunit (or any other project type) the config file project.nunit is only set up for the AppDomain if it exists, otherwise, we use the individual assembly configs.

This is not exactly a "breaking change" - it actually fixes something that was broken before - but it is a change in behavior.

Note that when multiple assemblies are made to run in the same AppDomain, there is no way for NUnit to give them separate config files.

rename.from: Specifying .nunit project and --framework on command line causes unit3-console.exe to crash.
rename.to: Specifying .nunit project and --framework on command line causes nunit3-console.exe to crash.

body:
This is still happening to me.

If I call `nunit3-console\nunit3-console.exe TestStack.White.nunit` I get the exception mentioned above.
If i directly use `nunit3-console\nunit3-console.exe ..\..\src\TestStack.White.UnitTests\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.UnitTests.dll` (which is what I added to the .nunit file) it works correctly.

Sure. See here: https://github.com/TestStack/White/blob/nunit/tools/NUnit/RunTests.bat
There I commented out the crashing call.
And I creatd it by hand, the tool always gave null ref. Exception when adding as assembly.

Your project uses the default for application base, which is the directory containing the project file. Your assemblies live outside of that base, so .NET cannot load them.

You can add the appbase attribute to either the Settings element or the config element.

Alternatively, the project editor does all this stuff for you.

I don't really get it. The nunit.framework.dll sits beside each assembly I want to test. So when giving the  assemblies directly to nunit3-console.exe it seems to use the path of the assembly to test as appbase. So each assembly there has it's own appbase. I don't see a way to do this with the .nunit file. Only a global appbase which is for all assemblies.

Okay, for some reason I got it working. This is the final file:

```
<NUnitProject>
  <Settings activeconfig="Debug" processModel="Default" domainUsage="Default" appbase="..\..\src" />
  <Config name="Debug" binpathtype="Auto" appbase="">
    <assembly path="TestStack.White.ScreenObjects\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.ScreenObjects.UITests.dll" />
    <assembly path="TestStack.White.UITests\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.UITests.dll" />
    <assembly path="TestStack.White.UnitTests\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.UnitTests.dll" />
    <assembly path="TestStack.White.WebBrowser.UITests\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.WebBrowser.UITests.dll" />
    <assembly path="TestStack.White.WebBrowser.UnitTests\bin\Debug\TestStack.White.WebBrowser.UnitTests.dll" />
  </Config>
</NUnitProject>
```

@Roemer Sounds like you do get it. :-) NUnit works differently for assemblies specified on the command-line and those listed in a project.

Assemblies on the command-line use the directory containing them as the application base if they are all run in different AppDomains. (If you force them into into the same AppDomain, NUnit tries to figure out a common base and errors if it can't find one.)

Assemblies in a project file default to using the location of that file as an appbase. You can change it for each config or globally, but not for each assembly. The logic for this is that allowing you to specify it for each assembly would create the possibility of several conflicts in the file, for which we would have to generate error messages. The current approach keeps it simple but does not allow you to place assemblies in a project unless they have a common appbase. We could conceivably change the default behavior, but this would be at the expense of having different defaults depending on the settings for domainUsage and processModel. I think that would be even more confusing.

Your project file changes are exactly what is needed. You could, of course, remove the Default entries, giving you

```
<Settings activeconfig="Debug" appbase="..\..\src" />
  <Config name="Debug">
```

As you discovered, a hand-edited project file must specify the path to each assembly relative to the ApplicationBase. Relative paths are used externally with absolute paths constructed upon execution. Using the Project Editor, the paths should always be saved in the correct format.
Thanks! Then I figured it out correctly! I think what you wrote above would fit somewhere in the wiki pretty good.

I think it's all on this page...
  https://github.com/nunit/nunit/wiki/NUnit-Project-XML-Format

Finding the page is the trick, even just now for me. :-)
Maybe I should add some of what I wrote here as a note.
Yes, and maybe a small example :) like the file I have not in the end.
